_prev_prog_3.Description:
Alkoxylation Process.



This process involves the use of two subject chemicals which are ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO).  These chemicals are stored in above ground storage tanks.  The raw materials EO and PO are batch transferred to reactors to make different products.  All safety interlocks are the same except that EO is now added to the batches through the new distributed control system (DCS)(logic control).  PHAs are conducted by product family.  For example, EO product, PO product, mix EO and PO, foamy stripping, powder addition, etc.  The latest PHA was conducted 9/13/12 covered all product families.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

Vantage considers the safety and health of all employees and contractors involved in its operations and of its customers, as well as the protection of the environment in which it operates to be of the utmost importance.

The Business will conduct its activities in accord with the Vantage Safety, Health and Environmental Policy which states:

We will ensure that all activities are conducted safely; the health of its employees, its customers and the public will be protected; environmental performance will meet regulatory requirements, and operations will be run in a manner acceptable to the local community.

Specifically, we will:

-Ensure that employees and contractors understand that nothing we do is worth getting hurt for.

-Comply with relevant laws and regulations and take any additional measures we consider necessary.

-Ensure that all our activities are being carried out in accordance with the company Safety, Health and Environment Standards.

-Set demanding targets and measure progress, to ensure continuous improvement in our safety, security, health and environmental performance.

-Require every employee to exercise personal responsibility in preventing harm to themselves, others and the environment, and enable them to contribute to every aspect of safety, security, health and environmental protection.

-Manufacture only those products that can be formulated, manufactured, transported, stored, used and disposed of safely.

-Seek to develop new or modified products which assist in conserving the environment and lead to sustainable development.

-Provide appropriate safety, security, health and environmental training and information for our employees, contractors and others who work with us, handle our products, or operate our technologies.

-Communicate openly on the nature of our activities and report progress on our safety, security, health and environmental performance.

-Enforce compliance

with Company safety, security and health policies including performance management where appropriate.

-Confirm to employees the Company's policy of non-retaliation for reporting injuries, illnesses or hazards that may exist at the workplace.

The facility and the regulated substance handled



VSC uses two (2) RMP regulated chemicals: ethylene oxide and propylene oxide as raw materials.  These chemicals are used to manufacture surfactants.  The end products of the Gurnee site using the RMP chemicals as raw materials are used for personal care, food additives and automotive coatings.  



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

To prevent accidental releases, this facility complies with EPA's Risk Management Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard . The facility's PSM program serves as the RMP Prevention Program.  The Prevention Program describes the policies and procedures in place to prevent and address accidental releases; these include Employee Participation, Process Hazard Analyses, Operating Procedures and Safe Work Practices, including Hot Work; Training, Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Contractors, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



The site uses a mix of control equipment, procedures and processes, and work practice controls to reduce the risk of releases of the subject chemicals.  These include:



a. A distributed control system (DCS) for process control which reduces the risk of an accidental release and responds automatically to prevent and/or mitigate the impact of a release in the event of a malfunction or unexpected event such as a power failure. A separate program logic controller (PLC) continuously monitors process safety parameters on equipment and activates controls to bring operations into a safe mode if parameters are exceeded; and,



b.  Emissions control devices, including wet and dry scrubbers which capture emissions of ethyl

ene oxide and propylene oxide from the manufacturing process. 



c.  A fugitive emissions and a leak detection program to detect leaks and fugitive emissions before they become a problem.



Five-year accident History

Vantage did not experience any accidents which met the reporting criteria. All incidents involving our RMP & PSM substances are investigated and appropriate corrective actions implemented to ensure we minimize the risk of similar/repeat incidents occurring.



Emergency Response Program

This facility has an emergency response plan that is coordinated with the community plan.  Vantage has a signed agreement with SET Environmental to respond in the event of an hazardous materials emergency. SET can be mobilized and onsite in less than 1 hour. The site is also equipped with water deluge systems the EO/PO Storage areas and process areas to suppress vapors, keep equipment cool and put out any fires. Air monitoring equipment is strategically staged to monitor for air borne flammable hazards and EO/PO specifically in the production room.  Local Police, Fire and EMS visit the site each year for a tour and training on the hazards of EO. Employees are trained how to identify an emergency and how to appropriately respond. There is an alert system at the site that is used to notify all employees of an emergency and the need to take action as well as two-way radio communications. There are layers of protection and redundant process control systems that will prevent or reduce the severity of a release.



The LEPC Coordinator for the county has been advised that the site is covered by the RMP regulations, has taken a tour of the facility, and maintains regular communication with the site.

Planned changes to improve safety

Processes are routinely changed to improve safety as a result of employee safety programs that include monthly safety meetings, daily pre-shift safety talks, employee process and safety training program, incident investigation and corrective a

ction programs, workplace audits and inspection programs, process safety, and safety awareness. Prevented maintenance programs continue to be utilized to identify equipment that need to be repaired/replaced to maintain safe operations.
